content.description:
Wildfire ascends an overhang via crimps, rails, and a fair amount of body tension.

Sit start with a small left hand bump and a right hand incut crimp. From there, crank up to a left hand edge (crux), work the feet up to the right, then cross over with a big right hand, gain the welcome shelf, traverse left a few feet, and top it out on the jugs.

I don't think it makes a lot of difference for the grade, but avoiding the platform with the feet out left at the end of the problem adds style to the problem.
content.protection: A few pads should do it, the landing is very good for this problem.
content.location:
This ascends the south face of Ritz Boulder. This problem shares the same start as

Lisenby Legacy

but opts out the direct finishes but traversing left on the good shelves.

content.description: Sit start with a right hand pinch on the arete and a left hand sloper-edge. From there, reach the jugs above, commit to the slab, and reach an easy mantle.
content.protection: A pad or two will work well. The landing is good, but there is a rock near the fall zone.
content.location: It climbs the west arete/face of Ritz.

content.description: Sit start with right and left hand sidepulls.  From there, traverse to the right on the shelf and edges for an easy mantle.
content.protection: A few pads, the landing is decent, but there are a few rocks.
content.location: This ascends the North face of the Ritz Boulder.

content.description:
Lisenby Legacy ascends a steep overhang on perfect holds over an ideal landing.

Sit start with a left hand bump and a right hand incut crimp. From there, make a big move to a left hand edge (crux), work the feet out right, cross over with the right to the rail, follow with the left to a jug to the left, then work straight up using an assortment of edges to reach a solid topout.
content.protection: A few pads should work well, the landing is very good for this problem.
content.location:
This ascends the south face of Ritz Rock. This problem shares the same start as

Wildfire

, but instead of going out left on the shelf, it finishes directly up the overhanging face.

content.description: Sit start with hands matched on the large shelf. From there, place a heel on the shelf, reach an edge, awkwardly position, gain another edge, then head straight up on jugs to reach an easy mantle.
content.protection: A pad will do. The landing is very good.
content.location: It climbs the center of Ritz's northwest face.

content.description: Sit start with a pair of edges and awkward feet. From there, bump the right hand up to a pinch, then follow with a left hand to an edge, reach the featured lip, and finish delicately up the stegasaurus land.
content.protection: Pad or two will work. The immediate landing is good, but there is a tree behind the problem.
content.location: It climbs the north face of Ritz.

content.description: Sit start with a pair of crimps. From there, reach a left hand crimp, reach an edge out right, then stand tall to the featured lip, and continue for the topout delicately through the featured finish.
content.protection: A pad or two will work fine. The landing is very good.
content.location: It climbs the north face of Ritz.

content.description:
Bring Your Beards climbs an undercut overhanging arete via thug compression. The problem maintains its difficulty from start to finish, climbs decent rock, and the landing is great.

Sit start with a left hand undercling-pinch and a right hand edge. From there, reach a left hand double-dimple, heel, bump the right hand up to an edge, bump the right again up to a sloper-edge, reach a left hand edge under the belly, adjust the heel, fall into a right hand edge, bring the left hand below the right on a good edge, cross over with the right to a big pinch, reach a left hand crimp, toe in, gain the right hand edge then the left hand edge, then finish it off using the good edges at the lip for an easy mantle.
content.protection: Three pads ideally. The landing is very good, but there is a rock that creates an uneven landing towards the end of the problem.
content.location: It climbs the undercut overhanging arete on the south face.

content.description: Sit start with a left hand sidepull and a right hand edge. From there, climb straight up through a series of edges, reach the lip, and delicately tread through the features for an easy mantle.
content.protection: A pad or two will work well. The landing is good in the immediate fall zone, but there is a rock behind the problem.
content.location: It climbs the north face of Ritz.
